text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

CCDM 35.10.1.1.3.2, dated August 11, 2004, was amended to incorporate the procedures described in Chief Counsel Notice CC-2009-018 (Procedures for the Payment of Awards of Litigation or Administrative Costs under Section 7430). Section 35.10.1.1.3.2 was also amended to include our current procedures with regard to an award payment offset.
Section 35.10.1.3.2 was added to incorporate the procedures in Chief Counsel Notice CC-2010-007 (Procedures for Evaluating and Responding to Qualified Offers Submitted under Section 7430(g)).
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
New Section 35.10.1.3.2 cross references new exhibits to be added to CCDM 35.11.1. These exhibits are sample letters for responding to valid and invalid qualified offers.

) The material in this chapter uses the term deficiency. Worker classification ployment tax cases under section
do not involve a deficiency (as in section
). The principles set forth below, however, apply to section cases as if the section

notice of determination were a notice of defi- ciency. In addition, decisions in certain post-assessment proceedings such interest abatement, spousal relief, and collection due process cases do not necessarily determine “deficiencies.” Often, such cases determine “liabilities” determine periods of interest abatement or other forms of relief. to the Internal Revenue Code. This section provides for awards of litigation and administrative costs to prevailing parties other than government in tax related suits in a court of the United States, including the Tax Court. For a discussion of attorneys’ fees suits filed in district courts and the Court of Federal Claims, please refer to CCDM Part

) Section

(a) provides that the prevailing party in any administrative or proceeding may be awarded a judgment for: a. Reasonable administrative costs incurred in connection with proceedings within the Internal Revenue Service, and b. Reasonable litigation costs incurred in connection with court (
) A prevailing party is defined as a taxpayer who substantially prevails as to amount in controversy or with respect to the most significant issue or set of issues. Section
)(A)(i); Treas. Reg. §
). A party will not be treated as the prevailing party if the government establishes that its position was substantially justified. Section

)(B)(i). The Service will found to be substantially justified where its position had a reasonable basis both law and fact. A position is also substantially justified if the position is justified to a degree that could satisfy a reasonable person. The Service’s position may be incorrect, but nevertheless be substantially justified if a rea- sonable person could think it correct. The taxpayer must also meet the net worth requirements of
U.S.C. §
)(B) to meet the definition of a prevailing party. (

) For litigation costs, the position of the United States is taken by the Service of the answer to the petition. For administrative costs, the position of the United States is taken as of the earlier of the date of the statutory notice of deficiency or the date of receipt by the taxpayer of the notice of the decision the Appeals Office. For purposes of section
, the Service treats a notice Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment and a notice of Final S Administrative Adjustment the same as a statutory notice of deficiency. (
) Expansion of Authority to Award Costs and Certain Fees. The Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
), Pub. L.
modified section

to allow for recoveries of reasonable trative costs back to the date of the first letter of proposed deficiency that allows a taxpayer an opportunity of administrative review in Appeals. The of determining the reasonableness of the Service’s determination, however, has not changed. This point remains at the time the matter is finally deter- mined by Appeals or at the time the notice of deficiency is issued. RRA
Chief Counsel Directives Manual
of Litigation and Costs and Fees 35.10.1
page 1

The Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act, Pub. L. No. 97–248 (TEFRA) added section 7430 to the Internal Revenue Code. This section provides for awards of litigation and administrative costs to prevailing parties other than government in tax related suits in a court of the United States, including the Tax Court. For a discussion of attorneys’ fees suits filed in district courts and the Court of Federal Claims, please refer to CCDM Part 36. It should also be noted that the Equal Access to Justice Act, Pub. L. 96–481, 94 Stat. 2325, does not apply to Tax Court proceedings. See 28 U.S.C. § 2412(e).
35.10.1.1.1 (01-06-2016) Motions for Attorneys’ Fees and Costs

Expansion of Authority to Award Costs and Certain Fees. The Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998 (RRA98), Pub. L. No. 105–206 modified section 7430 to allow for recoveries of reasonable adminis- trative costs back to the date of the first letter of proposed deficiency that allows a taxpayer an opportunity of administrative review in Appeals. The point of determining the reasonableness of the Service’s determination, however, has not changed. This point remains at the time the matter is finally deter- mined by Appeals or at the time the notice of deficiency is issued. RRA98 also

Special Procedures When Attorneys’ and Sanctions Are Sought raised the hourly rate cap to the amount provided in the Equal Access to Justice Act, expanded the reasons available for exceeding that hourly rate considered losses in other circuits to be relevant to the issue of substantial tification, allowed for the recovery of fees by pro bono representatives, and imposed a rule awarding litigation and administrative costs where the Service rejects a “qualified offer” during the “qualified offer period” and later recovers less than the amount offered even when the Service’s position was substan- tially justified as long as the other requirements of section
are met. (
) Section

has been amended several times since its enactment. As a of these amendments, the section applies in three different forms depending on the time period in which a case was commenced. As originally enacted, section
applied to cases commenced after February
, and January

for cases and administrative proceedings commenced after November
) Written Responses. Under T.C. Rule
(b), respondent is to file a written response to petitioner’s motion for an award of reasonable litigation or trative costs within

days after service of the motion. The court can also order respondent to file a written response to petitioner’s motion for an award of reasonable litigation or administrative costs a certain number of days than
days after service of the motion. In those cases, Field Counsel may consider requesting an extension to allow for the time period provided for in T.C. Rule

(b). The only situation in which a written response is not is when respondent is fully settling the cost issue. a. All written responses must be submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for review before filing with the court. See Exhibit
Requiring Associate Office Review). Responses shall contain the state- ments required by T.C. Rule

(b). To facilitate the preparation of the written response, early coordination with the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) is required. b. All written responses must be received by the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) at least ten calendar days before they must be filed with the court. The Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) will further coordinate all attorneys’ fees motions with the Associate office(s) controlling the underlying sub- stantive issue(s) of the case. c. When a written response has not been filed and the court grants an of litigation or administrative costs, Field Counsel should immediately notify the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A). Field Counsel should also consider filing a motion for reconsideration with the Tax Court. The for reconsideration must be received by the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for review at least five calendar days before it must be filed. d. In drafting a response or a motion for reconsideration, in addition to the elements required by T.C. Rule

(b), the response should include any matter inside or outside of the courtroom that unreasonably delayed the conclusion of the litigation, such as petitioner’s failure to comply with the court’s orders or refusal to stipulate to matters that fairly should have stipulated. The motion for reconsideration must be received by the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for review at least five calendar days before it must be filed. d. Litigation and Costs and Fees
page (
) This subsection discusses settlement authority. (
) Appeals, in docketed cases in which it proposes to agree to an award of tion or administrative costs, will prepare a memorandum stating the rationale for such an award. (
) Appeals will forward that memorandum to Field Counsel, along with the files, to evaluate such a settlement. Appeals will send a copy of the memorandum the Director of Appeals. (

) Field Counsel will independently evaluate the proposed settlement. If Field Counsel concurs with the settlement, Field Counsel will prepare a memoran- dum setting forth the reasons for accepting the settlement and explaining why the litigation or administrative costs are justified. The memorandum should discuss the statutory requirements embodied in section

) Field Counsel will send the memorandum and files to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A). All cases in which Field Counsel proposes to agree to an award of litigation or administrative costs must be submitted to the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) for approval prior to being filed with the court, with the exception of those that may be settled by Field Counsel. See Exhibit (Issues Requiring Associate Office Review). (

) With the following exceptions, the litigation or administrative cost issue in docketed Tax Court cases cannot be settled without the approval of the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A). Settlement authority has been delegated to Field Counsel in the following situations: a. The litigation costs settlement offer does not exceed $
and the ad- ministrative costs settlement offer does not exceed $

; b. The taxpayer has exhausted available administrative remedies; c. No prepetition expenses are awarded other than reasonable attorneys’ fees for the preparation and filing of a petition in the Tax Court; d. Payment for attorneys’ fees in excess of the hourly fee prescribed by statute may only be made where it is determined that the conditions for a higher hourly rate set forth in section

)(B)(iii) are likely to be satisfied by opposing counsel; e. Payment for attorneys’ fees in excess of the hourly fee prescribed by statute based on an increase in the cost of living may not be based on a period for the calculation of this increase beginning before January
; and f. In pro se cases only the filing fee and other reasonable court costs are be paid; no lost opportunity costs are to be included in the settlements. (
) The following settlements under section

require the approval of the Associate Chief Counsel (P&A) regardless of the amount involved: Counsel a. The settlement awards litigation costs for an individual authorized to practice before the Service but not before the Tax Court; or b. The settlement awards litigation costs incurred in an appeal to the Tax Court of the administrative denial of reasonable administrative costs (

Special Procedures When Attorneys’ and Sanctions Are Sought (
) This subsection discusses decision documents, payment of costs, and of awards. and (
) See CCDM
for a discussion of decision documents in cases attorneys’ fees under section

) Request for the Payment of Litigation and Administrative Costs. Awards for gation or administrative costs are paid from the General Judgment Fund. General Judgment Fund is administered by the Judgment Fund Branch, is a part of the Department of the Treasury Bureau of the Fiscal Service If litigation or administrative costs have been awarded in a Tax Court case, either as a result of litigation or settlement of the issue, Field Counsel to the case is assigned must do the following: a. Complete an Award Data Sheet. See Exhibit

To facilitate proper and expeditious handling of the litigation and administrative costs award, all of the information specified on the Award Data Sheet must be provided. Instructions on how to complete the items requested on the Award Data Sheet are provided in footnotes to the Award Data Sheet. this regard, particular attention should be given to item H, BRIEF STATEMENT OF WHY THE AWARD WAS MADE. As explained in the companying footnote, this should not be a statement of the legal issue. Similarly, a statement that the award was ordered by the court or our position was not substantially justified is not sufficient. The following are examples of acceptable statements: - “The taxpayer provided substantiation of his claimed Schedule C expenses to the Service prior to the issuance of the notice of deficiency. Consequently, the statutory notice should not have been issued. the issue was ultimately settled after the taxpayer filed a petition in the Court, the taxpayer unnecessarily was forced to incur attorney fees and costs to resolve the matter.” - “The taxpayer submitted a qualified offer that was not accepted by the Service. The amount of the taxpayer’s liability pursuant to the Tax decision is less than what the liability would have been under the offer had it been accepted by the Service. Therefore, the taxpayer is entitled to recover reasonable litigation costs pursuant to the qualified rule.”-“The Service’s position was not substantially justified because the Service lacked basis in fact for determining that the taxpayer was liable accumulated earnings tax when it had no facts about the taxpayer’s business plans and did not show whether case was diligently investi- gated.”-“Th

ervice’s position was not substantially justified because the Service relied on an unsupported notice of deficiency. In particular, the taxpayer had presented the Service documentation regarding the er’s earnings. The amount of earnings the taxpayer had reported on the taxpayer’s return was inconsistent with the amount the payor had
35.10 Special Procedures When Attorneys’ Fees and Sanctions Are Sought
This subsection discusses decision documents, payment of costs, and appeals
This subsection discusses decision documents, payment of costs, and appeals of awards.
either as a result of litigation or settlement of the issue, Field Counsel to whom the case is assigned must do the following: a. Complete an Award Data Sheet. See Exhibit

To facilitate the proper and expeditious handling of the litigation and administrative costs award, all of the information specified on the Award Data Sheet must be provided. Instructions on how to complete the items requested on the Award Data Sheet are provided in footnotes to the Award Data Sheet. In this regard, particular attention should be given to item H, BRIEF STATEMENT OF WHY THE AWARD WAS MADE. As explained in the ac- companying footnote, this should not be a statement of the legal issue. Similarly, a statement that the award was ordered by the court or our position was not substantially justified is not sufficient. The following are examples of acceptable statements: - “The taxpayer provided substantiation of his claimed Schedule C expenses to the Service prior to the issuance of the notice of deficiency. Consequently, the statutory notice should not have been issued. Although the issue was ultimately settled after the taxpayer filed a petition in the Court, the taxpayer unnecessarily was forced to incur attorney fees and costs to resolve the matter.” - “The taxpayer submitted a qualified offer that was not accepted by the Service. The amount of the taxpayer’s liability pursuant to the Tax Court’s decision is less than what the liability would have been under the qualified offer had it been accepted by the Service. Therefore, the taxpayer is entitled to recover reasonable litigation costs pursuant to the qualified rule.”-“The Service’s position was not substantially justified because the Service lacked basis in fact for determining that the taxpayer was liable accumulated earnings tax when it had no facts about the taxpayer’s business plans and did not show whether case was diligently investi- gated.”-“Th

ervice’s position was not substantially justified because the Service relied on an unsupported notice of deficiency. In particular, the taxpayer had presented the Service documentation regarding the taxpay- er’s earnings. The amount of earnings the taxpayer had reported on the taxpayer’s return was inconsistent with the amount the payor had reported

by the payor and unreliable.” b. Attach a copy of the entered decision reflecting the award to the Award Data Sheet. c. Constitution Avenue, N.W. Washington, D.C.
The Award Data Sheet and a copy of the entered decision should be mailed to the above address within

calendar days of the earlier of: a. the date the entered decision become final or b. if the entered decision is wholly adverse to the Government, the date Field Counsel is informed that the Government decided not to seek further review of the entered decision. d. See section (
) below regarding including instructions for offset in the Award Data Sheet. (

) Offset. If the entered decision reflects both a deficiency that is owed by the taxpayer and an award of litigation or administrative costs to the taxpayer, Field Counsel should state on the Award Data Sheet that an offset should be made and the amount of the offset. a. BFS will not offset interest. The amount of the award that is eligible to offset is limited to any unpaid deficiency that is determined in the entered decision that contains the award, exclusive of interest, regardless of whether the interest has been assessed. Consequently, do not include unpaid interest in the offset amount set forth in the Award Data Sheet. b. The award may only offset a deficiency for which a court has issued a judgment against the taxpayer, or for which the Service has issued a tax levy pursuant to section

In cases where a court decision both awards litigation and administrative costs and determines a deficiency, BFS will automatically offset the deficiency against the litigation and ad- ministrative costs award. Similarly, in cases where the Service has a tax levy, BFS will automatically offset the deficiency against the and administrative costs award. c. In cases where the court decision did not determine a deficiency or the deficiency is not reflected in any other court document such as an order judgment, then BFS will not automatically offset the litigation and trative costs award against the deficiency. Instead, BFS will request the taxpayer to consent to the offset. If the taxpayer consents to the offset, then BFS will proceed to offset the deficiency against the award. If the taxpayer does not consent to the offset, then BFS will consult with the Service and the Department of Justice about bringing a civil action to reduce the deficiency to a judgment. If the civil action is successful, then BFS will offset the amount of the judgment from the litigation and trative costs award. If the civil action is unsuccessful, then BFS will pay
The Award Data Sheet and a copy of the entered decision should be mailed to the above address within

calendar days of the earlier of: a. the date the entered decision become final or b. if the entered decision is wholly adverse to the Government, the date Field Counsel is informed that the Government decided not to seek further review of the entered decision. d. See section (
) below regarding including instructions for offset in the Award Data Sheet.

a. BFS will not offset interest. The amount of the award that is eligible to be offset is limited to any unpaid deficiency that is determined in the entered decision that contains the award, exclusive of interest, regardless of whether the interest has been assessed. Consequently, do not include unpaid interest in the offset amount set forth in the Award Data Sheet. b. The award may only offset a deficiency for which a court has issued a judgment against the taxpayer, or for which the Service has issued a tax levy pursuant to section

In cases where a court decision both awards litigation and administrative costs and determines a deficiency, BFS will automatically offset the deficiency against the litigation and ad- ministrative costs award. Similarly, in cases where the Service has issued a tax levy, BFS will automatically offset the deficiency against the litigation and administrative costs award. c. In cases where the court decision did not determine a deficiency or the deficiency is not reflected in any other court document such as an order judgment, then BFS will not automatically offset the litigation and adminis- trative costs award against the deficiency. Instead, BFS will request the taxpayer to consent to the offset. If the taxpayer consents to the offset, then BFS will proceed to offset the deficiency against the award. If the taxpayer does not consent to the offset, then BFS will consult with the Service and the Department of Justice about bringing a civil action to reduce the deficiency to a judgment. If the civil action is successful, then BFS will offset the amount of the judgment from the litigation and adminis- trative costs award. If the civil action is unsuccessful, then BFS will pay
35.10 Special Procedures When Attorneys’ and Sanctions Are Sought
the withheld amount to the taxpayer with interest accruing from the date when the payment would have been made. (

) Processing of Award. Upon receipt of the Award Data Sheet and entered decision, the Disclosure & Litigation Support Branch prepares the requisite BFS forms and submits the completed claim package to the BFS Judgment Fund Branch for processing and approval. See Exhibit
, Payment Memorandum with Offset, and Exhibit

, Payment Memorandum without Offset. When the litigation and administrative costs claim is approved by the Judgment Fund Branch, it is transferred electronically to the Financial Accounting and Services Division Accounting System (FASDAS) for payment. Certified payment requests are transmitted to Treasury’s Philadelphia Finance Center, which actually disburses the funds. a. The process described above should normally take six to eight weeks once the litigation and administrative costs award claim package is submitted to the Judgment Fund Branch. b. The submission of all paperwork to, and communications with, the Judgment Fund Branch and Treasury regarding the processing, status updates or payment of litigation and administrative costs awards are the sole responsibility of the Office of the Associate Chief Counsel and Administration). The Field Counsel assigned to the case should not communicate or send anything relating to the litigation and administrative costs award directly to the Judgment Fund Branch or other parts of Treasury. (

) Payment of the Award. To the extent that the administrative and litigation award exceeds the amount of the offset, if any, it is the policy and practice of the Office of Chief Counsel to have the award check issued in the name(s) of the taxpayer(s), not the taxpayer’s representative. The check is mailed, however, to the attention of the Field Counsel at the appropriate office address. Upon receipt, it is the responsibility of that Field Counsel to deliver the check to the taxpayer’s representative. The check should not be given to the taxpayer. This procedure was adopted by our office to avoid involvement fee disputes between the taxpayer and the taxpayer’s representative. a. There should be no deviation from this procedure unless the case pro bono representation. b. In the case of pro bono representation, the check should be made to the taxpayer’s pro bono representative, unless the Service is instructed by the representative, in writing, to pay the fee to the tative’s employer, such as a law firm. (
). Fees awarded for services provided by an employee of a pro bono clinic or organization, or a student affiliated with a pro bono clinic or nization, will be paid to the clinic or organization. (

). If an individual representative who is not an employee of a pro bono clinic or organization volunteers to provide services in affiliation with a bono clinic or organization, fee awards in that context will be paid to the clinic or organization.
the withheld amount to the taxpayer with interest accruing from the date when the payment would have been made.

Payment of the Award. To the extent that the administrative and litigation costs award exceeds the amount of the offset, if any, it is the policy and practice of the Office of Chief Counsel to have the award check issued in the name(s) of the taxpayer(s), not the taxpayer’s representative. The check is mailed, however, to the attention of the Field Counsel at the appropriate office address. Upon receipt, it is the responsibility of that Field Counsel to deliver the check to the taxpayer’s representative. The check should not be given to the taxpayer. This procedure was adopted by our office to avoid involvement in fee disputes between the taxpayer and the taxpayer’s representative.

and Costs and Fees
page (
) Under section

(f), an order granting or denying (in whole or in part) an award for administrative or litigation costs is incorporated as a part of the decision or judgment in the case and is subject to appeal in the same as the decision or judgment. T.C. Rule

(a) provides that the parties have days after the decision is entered to file a notice of appeal. Such an award appealable in the same manner as the decision or judgment and thus in “S” cases are not appealable. A decision granting or denying (in whole or part) an award for administrative costs at the administrative level is to the Tax Court for administrative proceedings commenced after November
) Section
), effective with respect to proceedings commenced after November
, establishes jurisdiction in the Tax Court to decide of taxpayers from decisions by the Internal Revenue Service denying for reasonable administrative costs within the meaning of section
) An action under T.C. Rule

is a separate litigation proceeding and is to distinguished from a proceeding initiated by a motion under the Tax Court Rules of Practice and Procedure involving a dispute with respect to litigation costs and administrative costs where a deficiency proceeding is already the Tax Court. See T.C. Rules

Not all rules of small case procedure are appli- cable. For example, answers are required to be filed in all such cases under T.C. Rule

of the Internal Revenue Service Restructuring and Reform Act
(RRA
), Pub. L. No.
, made several modifications to section
, including the addition of a qualified offer rule effective for costs after January

) In general, a prevailing party may recover the reasonable administrative and litigation costs incurred in administrative and court proceedings if the ings relate to the determination, collection, or refund of any tax, interest, or penalty under the Internal Revenue Code. Under the statute, as amended RRA

, the making of a qualified offer may result in the taxpayer being as a prevailing party for purposes of a recovery of costs. A taxpayer is a vailing party by reason of making a qualified offer if the taxpayer’s liability under the last qualified offer would equal or exceed the amount of the er’s liability under the judgment entered by the court. (
) Additional Requirements For Qualifying as a Prevailing Party. To qualify as a prevailing party under the statute, taxpayers must meet the net worth ments of section
)(A)(ii). Furthermore, to qualify for an award, taxpayers must meet the remaining requirements of section

, such as unreasonably protracting the proceedings and, for purposes of an award of litigation costs, exhausting their administrative remedies. a. A taxpayer cannot qualify as a prevailing party under the qualified offer rule if the determination of the court with respect to the adjustments included in the last qualified offer is issued pursuant to a settlement. (f), an order granting or denying (in whole or in part) an award for administrative or litigation costs is incorporated as a part of the decision or judgment in the case and is subject to appeal in the same manner as the decision or judgment. T.C. Rule

days after the decision is entered to file a notice of appeal. Such an award is appealable in the same manner as the decision or judgment and thus awards in “S” cases are not appealable. A taxpayer cannot qualify as a prevailing party under the qualified offer rule in any proceeding in which the amount of tax liability is not in issue, including any declaratory judgment proceeding, any proceeding to or quash any summons issued pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code, and any action to restrain disclosure under section

) A taxpayer qualifying as a prevailing party by reason of having made a qualified offer need not substantially prevail on either the amount in contro- versy or the most significant issue or set of issues presented. (
) Whether the positions of the United States in the administrative and proceedings were substantially justified is not relevant for an award under qualified offer rule. (

) The comparison of the taxpayer’s liability under the qualified offer with the liability under the judgment is central to the operation of the qualified offer For a complete discussion of liability under the last qualified offer and pursuant to the judgment, refer to Treas. Reg. §

) An award based upon the taxpayer having made a qualified offer is limited those reasonable administrative and litigation costs incurred on or after the date of the last qualified offer. If the taxpayer is a prevailing party without regard to the qualified offer rule, the reasonable administrative and litigation costs to which the taxpayer is thus entitled may not be awarded again by reason of the taxpayer having made a qualified offer. On the other hand, though some costs in a proceeding may be awarded without regard to the qualified offer rule, it is possible for other costs in the same proceeding to awarded under the qualified offer rule. For instance, costs incurred in portions of the proceedings or with regard to different adjustments at issue may be awarded under the qualified offer rule despite the awarding of other costs without regard to the qualified offer rule. (

) The qualified offer rule is intended to encourage settlement. Therefore, if the taxpayer makes a qualified offer and the Services settles the matter, either accepting the offer or by other means, the qualified offer rule does not for an award of fees. (

of Litigation and Costs and Fees 35.10.1
Specifies the Offered Amount of the Taxpayer’s Liability. To meet the require

ment that the offer specifies the offered amount of the taxpayer’s liability, the offer must clearly specify the amount for the taxpayer’s liability (determined without regard to interest unless interest is a contested issue). The offer may be a specific dollar amount of the total liability or a percentage of the adjust

ments at issue in the proceeding at the time the offer is made. The amount must be with respect to all of the adjustments at issue in the administrative or court proceeding at the time the offer is made and only those adjustments. The specified amount must be an amount, the acceptance of which by the United States will fully resolve the taxpayer’s liability, and only that liability for the type or types of tax and the taxable year or years at issue in the proceeding.

or types of tax and the taxable year or years at issue in the proceeding. a. An offer does not need to state that it is “without regard to interest.” Examples of compliant language include “Taxpayer offers $X in satisfac- tion of the tax liability and $Y in satisfaction of the penalty for tax year Z;” or “Taxpayer offers to concede X% of the tax liability and Y% of the penalty for tax year Z.” b. Interest may only be included in the offer if interest “is a contested issue in the proceeding.” Generally, interest is considered a contested issue only if the interest is specifically at issue in the proceeding independent of the taxpayer’s objections to the underlying tax imposed. Moreover, before interest can be at issue, the court in which the proceeding has been brought must have jurisdiction to determine the amount of interest due on the underlying tax, penalties, additions to tax and additional amounts, which is relatively rare. For an extensive discussion of the limitations of the Tax Court’s jurisdiction with respect to interest, particularly within settlements, refer to Smith v. Commissioner, T.C. Memo.

In Smith, the Tax Court explained that “[e]ven if the parties in a deficiency case unanimously requested it, the Court would not purport to enter a decision awarding or denying deficiency interest to the Commissioner.” Examples of cases in the Tax Court in which interest could be a contested issue are interest abatement cases under section

and transferee liability cases. The statutory notice should specify if interest has been assessed, which would indicate that the Tax Court has jurisdiction over interest. In contrast, the district court generally will have jurisdiction over interest in a refund case. See Commissioner v. M
oy,
U.S.

). c. For administrative proceedings prior to the commencement of a court pro- ceeding, interest will only be considered at issue if the Tax Court would have jurisdiction over interest once the taxpayer receives a statutory notice and files a petition. Unless and until a taxpayer full-pays the interest, no taxpayer may assert that interest is at issue because the district court could exercise jurisdiction over interest in a refund case. If the court would not have jurisdiction over interest, it cannot be a contested issue in the proceeding. , Period that the Offer Remains Open. Period that the Offer Remains Open. those dates. If such an offer were to remain open longer than those three minimum periods, it would not fail to meet this requirement. a. If no period is specified, the Service will presume the offer is open for the statutory period. b. Any offer that states it is open until withdrawn by the taxpayer will not be considered open for the statutory period. c. The taxpayer may extend the period the offer is open before it expires. (

) Made During the Qualified Offer Period. Aside from the minimum period which a qualified offer must remain open, a qualified offer must be made during the qualified offer period. That period begins with the date the first of proposed deficiency that allows the taxpayer an opportunity for review i

ppeals and it ends thirty days before the date the case is first set for trial. The qualified offer period will be extended if the case is removed from the calendar more than thirty days prior to the calendar call. In the United States Tax Court, cases are placed upon a calendar for trial and at the calendar call cases are scheduled for a specified day for trial during that trial calendar. sequently, in determining when the qualified offer period ends for cases in the Tax Court and other courts of the United States using calendars for trial, the Office of Chief Counsel will consider a case to be set for trial on the date scheduled for the calendar call. Cases may be removed from a trial calendar at any time. Thus, a case may be removed from a calendar before the date which is

days before the date scheduled for that calendar. In those cases, the qualified offer period does not end until the case remains on a trial calendar on the date that precedes by thirty days the scheduled date of the calendar call for that trial session. a. If the case is removed from the calendar more than
days prior to the original calendar date, then the qualified offer period remains open. b. If the case is removed within
days of the calendar date set, then the qualified offer period ends on the date that is

days prior to the scheduled date of the calendar call for that trial session. c. The qualified offer period may not be extended or reopened, although period during which a qualified offer remains open may extend beyond end of the qualified offer period. d. For example, if a case is first scheduled for trial on May
, the qualified offer period will end on April
If the case is continued on March
until July

If the case had been continued on April
until July
, then the offer period would not be extended and would end on April

In the United States Tax Court, cases are placed upon a calendar for trial and at the calendar call cases are scheduled for a specified day for trial during that trial calendar. days before the date scheduled for that calendar. In those cases, the qualified offer period does not end until the case remains on a trial calendar on the date that precedes by thirty days the scheduled date of the calendar call for that trial session.

) Procedure and Administration’s Review of the Offer. Branch
will review the purported qualified offer promptly and determine whether it meets the require- ments of sections

)(E) and (g). This review will include a determination as to whether the offer should be treated as a qualified offer, generally will not include a recommendation as to whether the offer should be accepted. The review and determination will be conveyed in a timely manner, mindful of allowing adequate time for the assigned attorney to effectuate the acceptance or rejection of the offer. (

) Response to the Offer. If a valid qualified offer is to be accepted, a written response should be prepared and sent. If it is determined that a valid offer should be rejected on the merits, then, on a case-by-case basis, either a written response should be sent or the offer should be allowed to lapse. If it is determined that the offer is not a valid qualified offer, a written response be prepared and sent either accepting the offer on its merits as a regular settlement offer or rejecting the offer on its merits. a. All written responses should include the following: - State if the offer is a valid qualified offer. - State whether the Service will accept or reject the offer. - Describe briefly the Service’s understanding of the terms of the offer. - If the offer is not a qualified offer, explain why that is so, and (if the offer is not accepted) how the offer could be revised to constitute a qualified offer.-Affirmatively request that, if the Service has misconstrued the offer, peti- tioner’s representative reply in writing explaining the misunderstanding regarding the offer. b. Prior to being sent to the petitioner(s)’ representative, all written should be submitted to Procedure and Administration Branch
via email to TSS
for review. To help expedite this review process, a copy should also be e-mailed directly to the Branch
attorney who reviewed the offer or, if one cannot be identified, the Branch Chief. (
) Sample letters. For sample letters accepting or rejecting a valid qualified offer see Exhibits
and
